question: Question_02_(c)
statement:
Consider the function

\[f(x) = \frac{x^3+x^2-2x-3}{x^2-3}.\]

Its first and second derivatives are given by

\[f'(x) = \frac{(x^2-1)(x^2-6)}{(x^2-3)^2}, \qquad f''(x) = \frac{2x(x^2+9)}{(x^2-3)^3}.\]

On what intervals is f(x) increasing? On what intervals is f(x)
decreasing?
sols:
Factoring the derivative yields

\[f'(x) = \frac{(x-1)(x+1)(x-\sqrt 6)(x+\sqrt 6)}{(x-\sqrt 3)^2(x+\sqrt 3)^2}\]

Now the following sign table is straight forward:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllllll@{}}
& $(-\infty;-\sqrt 6)$ & $(-\sqrt 6; -\sqrt 3)$ & $(-\sqrt 3; -1)$ &
$\displaystyle (-1;1)$ & $(1; \sqrt 3)$ & $(\sqrt 3; \sqrt 6)$ &
$(\sqrt 6; \infty)$\\
$\displaystyle x-1$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$\displaystyle x+1$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$x-\sqrt 6$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$
& $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle +$\\
$x+\sqrt 6$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$
& $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$\\
$(x-\sqrt 3)^2$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$(x+\sqrt 3)^2$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$\displaystyle f'(x)$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$\displaystyle f(x)$ & $\displaystyle \nearrow$ &
$\displaystyle \searrow$ & $\displaystyle \searrow$ &
$\displaystyle \nearrow$ & $\displaystyle \searrow$ &
$\displaystyle \searrow$ & $\displaystyle \nearrow$\\
\end{longtable}

And so we can conclude that the function is increasing on:

\[(- \infty,-\sqrt 6 ) \cup (-1,1) \cup (\sqrt6,\infty)\] and decreasing
on:

\[(- \sqrt 6,-\sqrt 3 ) \cup (-\sqrt 3,-1) \cup (1,\sqrt 3) \cup (\sqrt3,\sqrt 6)\]

\textbf{If you don't like a sign table:}

From Question 2 (a), we know that the critical points of $f(x)$,
when $f'(x)$ or does not exist, are at \emph{x} = ±1, ±, and ±.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Testing a value less than -, such as -3, we get $f$'(-3) = 2/3
  \textgreater{} 0.
\item
  Testing a point between - and -, such as -2, yields $f$'(-2) = -2
  \textless{} 0.
\item
  Testing a point between - and -1, such as -1.5, we get $f$'(-1.5) =
  -25/3 \textless{} 0.
\item
  Finally, we test a point between -1 and 1, such as 0, and get $f$'(0) =
  2/3 \textgreater{} 0.
\end{itemize}

Normally, we would have to test points between the positive critical
points as well, but since our function only has
\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} terms in it (\emph{i.e. $f$' is even}), we
know that our negative test points will have identical values to their
corresponding positive test points.

(For example, testing -2 and 2 produce identical values of -2, so
$f(x)$ \textless{} 0 between - and - as well as between and .)

\textbf{Therefore:} $f(x)$ is

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  increasing on the intervals
  $(- \infty,-\sqrt 6 ) \cup (-1,1) \cup (\sqrt6,\infty)$
\end{itemize}

and

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  decreasing on the intervals
  $(- \sqrt 6,-\sqrt 3 ) \cup (-\sqrt 3,-1) \cup (1,\sqrt 3) \cup (\sqrt3,\sqrt 6)$.
\end{itemize}

\emph{Note that the critical points are not included in the intervals of
increase and decrease.}
hints:
A differentiable function is increasing on an interval if its derivative
is positive on that interval. What would a sign table of the derivative
tell you then?

\textbf{If you don't like a sign table:} In question 2 (a), we
determined where \emph{f'(x)=0} or does not exist, i.e. the critical
points of \emph{f(x)}. Try testing the sign of \emph{f}' for values
between two adjacent critical points.
